query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Cantando come donna innamorata, 2 continüò col fin di sue parole: 3 ‘Beati quorum tecta sunt peccata!’.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Singing like a woman in love, 2 she continued with the end of her words: 3 ‘Blessed are those whose sins are covered!’**Cornish:**
1 Yn kanna mardh karow, 2 hi a leveris gans diwettha y ger, 3 ‘Syw benowgas an re beudh y pechodhow gwiskys!’

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
4 E come ninfe che si givan sole 5 per le salvatiche ombre, disïando 6 qual di veder, qual di fuggir lo sole,
7 allor si mosse contra ’l fiume, andando 8 su per la riva; e io pari di lei, 9 picciol passo con picciol seguitando.
query.result:
**English:**
4 And like nymphs who wander alone 5 through the wild shadows, desiring 6 one to see, one to flee the sun,
7 then she moved against the river, walking 8 along the bank; and I beside her, 9 following with small steps her small steps.**Cornish:**
4 Ha kepar nymphys ow tos onan 5 a-dreus an scouthow gwyls, ow tos karow 6 onan rag gweles, onan rag kerdhes an howl,
7 henna prys hi a gavas orth an avon, ow tos 8 war an glann; ha my a-dhyworth ythoma, 9 ow sywya byghan gans byghan ow sywya.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
10 Non eran cento tra ’ suoi passi e ’ miei, 11 quando le ripe igualmente dier volta, 12 per modo ch’a levante mi rendei.
query.result:
**English:**
10 There were not a hundred between his steps and mine, 11 when the banks turned equally, 12 so that I turned to the east.**Cornish:**
10 Na veu kans ugans yntra y gammow ha’m, 11 pan wrug an glannow yn keth dhe dro, 12 rag fordh ow thrug y’n est.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 Né ancor fu così nostra via molta, 14 quando la donna tutta a me si torse, 15 dicendo: «Frate mio, guarda e ascolta».
query.result:
**English:**
13 Nor had our way been so long, 14 when the lady turned completely to me, 15 saying: “My brother, look and listen.”**Cornish:**
13 Ha na veu an fordh henna mor a’gan fordh, 14 pan wrug an wragh yn keth dhe’m, 15 ow leverel: “Froder vy, sel ha klev.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
16 Ed ecco un lustro sùbito trascorse 17 da tutte parti per la gran foresta, 18 tal che di balenar mi mise in forse.
query.result:
**English:**
16 And behold, a sudden brightness flashed 17 from every side through the great forest, 18 so that it made me uncertain whether it was lightning.
**Cornish:**
16 Ha gwel, golowder a-dhryskens, 17 a-dro dhe bub tu dhe'n koedh bras, 18 hemma a wrug dhymm dheus dhe wodha golowder.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
19 Ma perché ’l balenar, come vien, resta, 20 e quel, durando, più e più splendeva, 21 nel mio pensier dicea: ‘Che cosa è questa?’.
query.result:
**English:**
19 But why does lightning, as soon as it comes, cease, 20 and that, enduring, shines more and more brightly, 21 in my thoughts I said: ‘What is this?’.
**Cornish:**
19 Mes, ragadha'n golowder, dell yw hedha, a wra, 20 ha henna, ow trwa, moy ha moy a splanna, 21 yn y fedhansow, me a leveris: ‘Pyth yw henna?’.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
22 E una melodia dolce correva 23 per l’aere luminoso; onde buon zelo 24 mi fé riprender l’ardimento d’Eva,
25 che là dove ubidia la terra e ’l cielo, 26 femmina, sola e pur testé formata, 27 non sofferse di star sotto alcun velo;
28 sotto ’l qual se divota fosse stata, 29 avrei quelle ineffabili delizie 30 sentite prima e più lunga fïata.
query.result:
**English:**
22 And a sweet melody flowed 23 through the luminous air; whence a good zeal 24 made me take up again the daring of Eve,
25 who there where earth and heaven obeyed, 26 a woman, alone and only just created, 27 did not endure to remain under any veil;
28 under which if she had been devout, 29 I would have felt those ineffable delights 30 earlier and for a longer time.
**Cornish:**
22 Ha son meur a redegyas 23 a-dreus an ebron golow, ragadha da vad gel 24 a wrug dhymm kemer an feth Eva,
25 neb ena, le mayth an nor ha'n nef, 26 benen, onan ha nowydh furvys, 27 ny wodha soffrya dhe vos sewyth dan nen gorhel;
28 dan henna, pub travia devos o ve, 29 vyth ow feusa an nebesow diwydh hynwys 30 moy a-var ha moy hirra prys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 Mentr’ io m’andava tra tante primizie 32 de l’etterno piacer tutto sospeso, 33 e disïoso ancora a più letizie,
34 dinanzi a noi, tal quale un foco acceso, 35 ci si fé l’aere sotto i verdi rami; 36 e ’l dolce suon per canti era già inteso.
query.result:
**English:**
31 While I was going among so many first-fruits 32 of eternal pleasure, all in suspense, 33 and still desiring more joys,
34 before us, like a burning fire, 35 the air became beneath the green boughs; 36 and the sweet sound was already heard as songs.
**Cornish:**
31 Tra ve'm o mos ow tos ha tressa kynsa 32 a'n pleser sempiternel, oll owth omset, 33 ha owth owsynna moy a lowena,
34 rag y'n kensa, kepar tan tan owth omloskys, 35 an ebron a wrug dhymm dan an geyn gwyrdh; 36 ha'n son meur a veu klevys kepar kana.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 O sacrosante Vergini, se fami, 38 freddi o vigilie mai per voi soffersi, 39 cagion mi sprona ch’io mercé vi chiami.
query.result:
**English:**
37 O sacred Virgins, if I ever suffered 38 cold or vigils for you, 39 the reason spurs me to call on you for mercy.
**Cornish:**
37 O Wyrgynysi sans, pub travia vy 38 oergwelyow po gwylyow rag y'n keveris, 39 an achos a wra'm ow spronya dhe galwas tru.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
40 Or convien che Elicona per me versi, 41 e Uranìe m’aiuti col suo coro 42 forti cose a pensar mettere in versi.
query.result:
**English:**
40 Now it is fitting that Helicon pour forth for me, 41 and Urania help me with her choir 42 to think of strong things to put into verse.
**Cornish:**
40 Mes lemmyn wra Elikona ow tos dhe vesi, 41 hag Ourania ow skoedha dhymm gans y gan, 42 dhe fedha kres dhe vos ow pos dhe vers.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
43 Poco più oltre, sette alberi d’oro 44 falsava nel parere il lungo tratto 45 del mezzo ch’era ancor tra noi e loro;
46 ma quand’ i’ fui sì presso di lor fatto, 47 che l’obietto comun, che ’l senso inganna, 48 non perdea per distanza alcun suo atto,
49 la virtù ch’a ragion discorso ammanna, 50 sì com’ elli eran candelabri apprese, 51 e ne le voci del cantare ‘Osanna’.
query.result:
**English:**
43 A little further on, seven trees of gold 44 falsified in appearance the long stretch 45 of the middle that was still between us and them;
46 but when I had come so near to them, 47 that the common object, which deceives the sense, 48 did not lose any of its form through distance,
49 the power that rightly prepares discourse, 50 perceived that they were candelabra, 51 and in the voices of the song ‘Hosanna’.
**Cornish:**
43 Bys vythenn moy a-ves, seyth pren a our 44 a wrug an golwg falsya an hir bell 45 a'n kres o veu bynnertha ni ha henna;
46 mes pan veu ow tos owth omset dhe'n kres, 47 an gweladow kemmyn, neb a drueth an golwg, 48 ny wodha kolli neb onan a'y furv,
49 an gallos owth ow tos dhe reson galwas, 50 a welas ow tos kandelabrow, 51 ha'n leusow a'n kana 'Osanna'.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 Di sopra fiammeggiava il bello arnese 53 più chiaro assai che luna per sereno 54 di mezza notte nel suo mezzo mese.
query.result:
**English:**
52 Above, the beautiful harness was blazing 53 much brighter than the moon in the clear 54 of midnight in the middle of its month.
**Cornish:**
52 A-ugh an arnes meur a veu ow flammia, 53 moy klerhe ages an loer yn serenn 54 a-ves nos ow kresel y mis ow kres.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 Io mi rivolsi d’ammirazion pieno 56 al buon Virgilio, ed esso mi rispuose 57 con vista carca di stupor non meno.
query.result:
**English:**
55 I turned to him, full of amazement, 56 to the good Virgil, and he answered me 57 with a gaze no less laden with astonishment.
**Cornish:**
55 Me a droas dhe'n kres, leun a omset, 56 dhe Virgili meur da, ha henna a leveris 57 gans golwg leun a omset, pub tra.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 Indi rendei l’aspetto a l’alte cose 59 che si movieno incontr’ a noi sì tardi, 60 che foran vinte da novelle spose.
query.result:
**English:**
58 Then I turned my gaze back to the lofty things 59 that were moving towards us so slowly, 60 that they would have been overtaken by new brides.
**Cornish:**
58 Wosa henna me a droas y'm golwg dhe'n traow meur 59 ow tos ow tos dhe'n kres owth omset a-hwel, 60 ow tos ow fe vethens gans pridow nowydh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 La donna mi sgridò: «Perché pur ardi 62 sì ne l’affetto de le vive luci, 63 e ciò che vien di retro a lor non guardi?».
query.result:
**English:**
61 The lady scolded me: "Why do you burn so 62 in the affection of the living lights, 63 and do not look at what comes behind them?".
**Cornish:**
61 An venen a'm kerghas: "Perag orth agan 62 yn karanteth an golow bew, 63 ha'n wra vyth orth an pyth a dheu?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 Genti vid’ io allor, come a lor duci, 65 venire appresso, vestite di bianco; 66 e tal candor di qua già mai non fuci.
query.result:
**English:**
64 I saw people then, as it seemed to me, 65 coming after them, dressed in white; 66 and such whiteness was never seen here before.
**Cornish:**
64 Gweles vyth tus a dus, dell orth aga, 65 ow tos yn ke dheu, gwyn o aga dilla; 66 ha'n wynn gwynvel avel henna nyns yw gwelys erbynn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 L’acqua imprendëa dal sinistro fianco, 68 e rendea me la mia sinistra costa, 69 s’io riguardava in lei, come specchio anco.
query.result:
**English:**
67 The water began on the left flank, 68 and it gave back to me my left side, 69 if I looked into it, like a mirror also.
**Cornish:**
67 An dowr a dhallathas war an tu klew, 68 ha'n dhallathas dhe'm ow tu klew, 69 mar ke'm gwelasen y'nni, dell orth yn jynn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 Quand’ io da la mia riva ebbi tal posta, 71 che solo il fiume mi facea distante, 72 per veder meglio ai passi diedi sosta,
73 e vidi le fiammelle andar davante, 74 lasciando dietro a sé l’aere dipinto, 75 e di tratti pennelli avean sembiante;
76 sì che lì sopra rimanea distinto 77 di sette liste, tutte in quei colori 78 onde fa l’arco il Sole e Delia il cinto.
query.result:
**English:**
70 When I had reached such a position from my bank, 71 that only the river made me distant, 72 to see better I paused in my steps,
73 and I saw the little flames go before, 74 leaving the air painted behind them, 75 and they had the appearance of drawn brushes;
76 so that above them remained distinct 77 seven bands, all in those colors 78 from which the Sun makes the rainbow and the Moon her belt.
**Cornish:**
70 Pan wosa vyth ow pos dhe'm ow tu klew, 71 mar an avon hep ow tos dhe'm, 72 rag gwell gweles ow tos ow sosta,
73 ha gweles vyth an flamow ow tos orth, 74 ow tos an ayr ow peynti dhe'u, 75 ha'ga semlant pennow trehes aga;
76 mar war aga ow tos ow remanath 77 seyth list, oll yn aga liwow, 78 orth aga liwow an Howl a wra an Dell an gwregys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 Questi ostendali in dietro eran maggiori 80 che la mia vista; e, quanto a mio avviso, 81 diece passi distavan quei di fori.
query.result:
**English:**
79 These banners behind were larger 80 than my sight; and, as far as I could tell, 81 those on the outside were ten paces apart.
**Cornish:**
79 An ostendali ma ow tos ow moy ages 80 ages ow gweles; ha, mar ow tysons, 81 deg pas ow tos aga orth an mes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
82 Sotto così bel ciel com’ io diviso, 83 ventiquattro seniori, a due a due, 84 coronati venien di fiordaliso.
query.result:
**English:**
82 Under such a beautiful sky as I have described, 83 twenty-four elders, two by two, 84 crowned with fleur-de-lis, were coming.
**Cornish:**
82 Danow an keth bel avel dell ow tysons, 83 dew ha ugens ugans, dew ha dew, 84 ow tos coronys gans flordaliso.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 Tutti cantavan: «Benedicta tue 86 ne le figlie d’Adamo, e benedette 87 sieno in etterno le bellezze tue!».
query.result:
**English:**
85 All sang: "Blessed art thou 86 among the daughters of Adam, and blessed 87 be thy beauties forever!".
**Cornish:**
85 Oll ow kanas: "Benedicta thu 86 y'mysk mergh Adam, ha benedicta 87 byth fytho an jynn bewow thu!".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 Poscia che i fiori e l’altre fresche erbette 89 a rimpetto di me da l’altra sponda 90 libere fuor da quelle genti elette,
91 sì come luce luce in ciel seconda, 92 vennero appresso lor quattro animali, 93 coronati ciascun di verde fronda.
query.result:
**English:**
88 After the flowers and the other fresh grasses 89 opposite me on the other bank 90 were free from those chosen people,
91 just as one light follows another in the sky, 92 four animals came after them, 93 each crowned with a green branch.
**Cornish:**
88 Wosa an bleujow ha'n erel erbow fres 89 orth ow tos dhe'm war an tu aral, 90 ow tos dibris dhe'u an dus an dus ethol,
91 dell orth golow golow yn keth nessa, 92 peswar anvales ow tos dhe'u, 93 coronys pub onan gans frondow gwer.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 Ognuno era pennuto di sei ali; 95 le penne piene d’occhi; e li occhi d’Argo, 96 se fosser vivi, sarebber cotali.
query.result:
**English:**
94 Each one was feathered with six wings; 95 the feathers full of eyes; and the eyes of Argus, 96 if they were alive, would be like these.
**Cornish:**
94 Pub onan ow tos pennys gans whegh esel; 95 an pennow leun gans lagha; ha lagha Argo, 96 mar aga ow tos bew, aga ow tos cothel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
106 Lo spazio dentro a lor quattro contenne 107 un carro, in su due rote, trïunfale, 108 ch’al collo d’un grifon tirato venne.
query.result:
**English:**
106 The space within them contained 107 a triumphal chariot, on two wheels, 108 which was drawn by the neck of a griffin.
**Cornish:**
106 An spys ynter aga peswar a gomprehendyas 107 on kar, warbarth dew roda, tryumfal, 108 ow a veu tynnerghys on gryffyn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 Esso tendeva in sù l’una e l’altra ale 110 tra la mezzana e le tre e tre liste, 111 sì ch’a nulla, fendendo, facea male.
query.result:
**English:**
109 It stretched upwards on one wing and the other 110 between the middle list and the three and three, 111 so that, cleaving through, it harmed nothing.
**Cornish:**
109 Ev a estendas warbarth an eyl ha'n eyl aral 110 ynter an list kentrek ha'n tri ha tri, 111 marnas dhefendya, na wrug ev drok dhe nagon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 Tanto salivan che non eran viste; 113 le membra d’oro avea quant’ era uccello, 114 e bianche l’altre, di vermiglio miste.
query.result:
**English:**
112 They flew so high that they could not be seen; 113 the parts of it that were like a bird were of gold, 114 and the other parts were white, mixed with vermilion.
**Cornish:**
112 Ev a hedhas mar ughel na veuir ev; 113 an ranniow a-our o ev a veu avel orth ethen, 114 ha'n remenans o veu gwyn, meskys gans rudh.

**English:**
121 Three women were dancing in a circle around the right wheel; 122 one was so red 123 that she would hardly have been noticed inside a fire;
124 the second was as if her flesh and bones 125 had been made of emerald; 126 the third seemed like snow that had just fallen;
127 and now they seemed to be led by the white one, 128 now by the red one; and from the song of this one 129 the others took their steps, slow and fast.
**Cornish:**
121 Tri benen y’n dro dhe'n rota dhe dhehu, 122 ow tos o dansya; unn o veu mar rudh 123 marnas ev a veu merghys y’n tan.
124 An nessa o veu mar avel henna e'y kig hag eskern 125 o veu gwres gans smaragd; 126 an nessa nessa o seblans ergh nowydh.
127 Ha lemmyn ev a seblans dhe ledyes gans an wenn, 128 lemmyn gans an rudh; ha gans kan an nessa na 129 an nessa nessa a gemereth aga kerdhes, araf ha bys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 Da la sinistra quattro facean festa, 131 in porpore vestite, dietro al modo 132 d’una di lor ch’avea tre occhi in testa.
query.result:
**English:**
130 On the left, four were making merry, 131 dressed in purple, following the fashion 132 of one of them who had three eyes in her head.
**Cornish:**
130 Warbarth an klew, peswar o wrug festa, 131 ow wiska gans purpur, wosa'n fordh 132 unn aga honan tri lagha y’n fen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 Appresso tutto il pertrattato nodo 134 vidi due vecchi in abito dispari, 135 ma pari in atto e onesto e sodo.
query.result:
**English:**
133 After all the aforementioned group 134 I saw two old men in different clothing, 135 but similar in their dignified and serious bearing.
**Cornish:**
133 Wosa henna oll an pertrattas knot, 134 y’m gwelas dew gogh yn wiskogh dyffrans, 135 mes par yn aga gweyth, onest ha sodho.

**English:**
136 One of them appeared to be one of the disciples 137 of that great Hippocrates whom nature 138 made dearer to her than all other animals;
139 the other showed the opposite concern 140 with a shining and sharp sword, 141 such that it frightened me on this side of the river.
**Cornish:**
136 Unn aga o wrug diskwedhes onan a'n servansow 137 a henna Ipokratis meur, ow a wrug natur 138 dhe wul an enevalow mar dha garas.
139 An nessa o wrug diskwedhes an gowsans contrar 140 gans kledha skler ha lemm, 141 marnas ev a wrug ow a-dhelergh dhe'n avon na.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
142 Poi vidi quattro in umile paruta; 143 e di retro da tutti un vecchio solo 144 venir, dormendo, con la faccia arguta.
query.result:
**English:**
142 Then I saw four in humble guise; 143 and behind them all, an old man alone 144 came, sleeping, with a sharp face.
**Cornish:**
142 Wosa henna y’m gwelas peswar yn paruta goen, 143 ha wosa aga oll, onan koth a-unnik 144 ow tos, ow kouskya, gans an fas arguta.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
145 E questi sette col primaio stuolo 146 erano abitüati, ma di gigli 147 dintorno al capo non facëan brolo,
148 anzi di rose e d’altri fior vermigli; 149 giurato avria poco lontano aspetto 150 che tutti ardesser di sopra da’ cigli.
query.result:
**English:**
145 And these seven, with the first group, 146 were garlanded, but they did not make a garland 147 of lilies around their heads,
148 but of roses and other red flowers; 149 one who saw them from a distance would have sworn 150 that they were all burning from their eyebrows up.
**Cornish:**
145 Ha'n seyth na, gans an kynsa studh, 146 o veu wiskes, mes na wrug ev brolo 147 a-dro dhe'n pen gans lilys,
148 mes gans rosow ha bleujyn vermil erel; 149 ow a veu lowen, ow a veu dhe wul dhelergh, 150 ev oll o veu ow tos ow kovya a-ugh dhe'n lagha.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
151 E quando il carro a me fu a rimpetto, 152 un tuon s’udì, e quelle genti degne 153 parvero aver l’andar più interdetto,
154 fermandosi ivi con le prime insegne.
query.result:
**English:**
151 And when the chariot was opposite me, 152 a thunderclap was heard, and those worthy people 153 seemed to have their progress further impeded,
154 stopping there with the foremost banners.
**Cornish:**
151 Ha pan vynns an karros dhe'm, 152 un ton a veu klevys, ha'n dus dus 153 a welas kyn fe an fordh moy es,
154 ow talleth ena gans an kynsa baner.
